<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of named_thread_starter:
```c
static MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_
named_thread_starter (void *data)
{
  struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *const param =
    (struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *) data;
  void *arg;
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;

  if (NULL == data)
    return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0;

  MHD_set_cur_thread_name_ (param->name);

  arg = param->arg;
  thr_func = param->start_routine;
  free (data);

  return thr_func (arg);
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: The remaining lines in the function are simple declarations, a null check and a cast/assignment that do not themselves invoke any string-handling functions from <string.h>. Specifically, the function signature and local variable declarations, the initial cast/assignment of data to param, the NULL check and the early return, and the typed cast in the return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0; do not perform string operations and therefore do not need investigation for Rule 21.17. The only places that could lead to out-of-bounds string accesses are calls that pass character/string pointers or hand off pointers to other routines (which are listed above). No other lines in the snippet call or manipulate string.h functions.
